I'm is passionate about self-development, life experiences, human performance, and helping others grow. What's up everybody? Eric here. Welcome back to all outliers. A big shout out to the YouTube members and the Patreon folks. If you're interested in joining and supporting you can find the links in the description below. And with that, let's get right to it. So the very first thing, there's going to be five steps here. And at the end, the fifth step is going to walk us through some of the best practices that I've learned both from my personal experience, but then also observing other people in their natural habitat, working on these kinds of things. So the very first one is one I reference all the time. This is from Stephen Covey's Seven Habits of Highly Successful People, begin with the end in mind. This is in the Marine Corps, what we would call the desired end state. What are we trying to do? And most commonly, it's some derivative of this replace my income. The next step is we now need to take that end state, replacing our income, and we need to project it out in time. And then we need to quantify things. So these are the questions you have to ask yourself. When are you attempting to replace your income with your investing income? How much is your current income? A.K. How much investing income do you need? What are your expenses and what are your margins? This isn't necessarily used directly in these formulas. I'm going to share in a little bit, but it is more going to be a thing we want to track. Because that's going to be one of the most impactful early levers you can pull on to get your desired outcome. And then the last one is your future income references. This one is super important because a lot of people, when they're talking about this kind of planning, they tend to be super, super conservative. The reason why I differentiate between these two is because I do not personally want to have to maintain essentially my top line performance into perpetuity in order to live off of it. The very stressful way to do things. So the way that I think about it is we have a growth phase where we're more aggressive more on top of it. But then we ease off the gas once we start getting closer to our metric so that we can actually just fuck out a little bit. Enjoy the stuff that we're working on. So think of it

And then the last thing here is CPI, continual process or continuous process improvements, exactly what it sounds like. These little things, none of this is complex. This is why I like investing so much, is because a knee and a thaw like myself can do this. All you have to do is create a little bit of planning, so metrics around that ultimate goal, and then go for it. But one of the worst possible things you could do is just think that life is gonna magic you there, because you're gonna look back after 20 years, you're gonna say, what the fuck just happened? And guess what, those 20 years are gonna be your best, possible compounding years that exists. So if this video is helpful, like share it with other people that need to do this, subscribe, be an outlier. I'll see you guys later.
